summary: A letter from the U.S. Department of Justice, Southern District of New York, to attorney Gloria Allred, notifying her of her designation to receive victim notifications on behalf of certain victims in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. It outlines victim rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act and provides details about an upcoming arraignment.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: Addressee of the letter, designated to receive notifications on behalf of victims in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The individual against whom charges have been filed; the subject of the criminal case.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signatory of the letter, representing the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The judge before whom Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment is scheduled.

connections.description: Allred is designated to receive legal notifications on behalf of victims in the criminal case against Maxwell.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is part of the office prosecuting the case against Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the arraignment and subsequent proceedings in Maxwell's case.

events.title: Arraignment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Scheduled arraignment before Judge Alison Nathan where Maxwell is expected to enter a plea to the charges.

locations: One St. Andrews Plaza, New York, NY 10007
6300 Wilshire Blvd. Suite 1500, Los Angeles, CA 90048
Clerk's Office, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Charges have been filed against Ghislaine Maxwell under Case Number 2020R00719 / Docket 20-CR-00330, categorized as a Project Safe Childhood case.
Attorney Gloria Allred has been officially designated to receive victim notifications on behalf of victims identified in the investigation.
An arraignment is scheduled for July 14, 2020, before Judge Alison Nathan, where the government expects Maxwell to plead not guilty.
The letter details the specific rights afforded to victims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (Title 18 U.S.C. ยง 3771).
The lead prosecutor's name is redacted in the document, indicating a standard practice of withholding certain operational details in victim notifications.
